instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Keyboard/Trackpad
threads.message: This board had some minor liquid-damage but nothing near the keyboard or trackpad connector. The board works fine but has no trackpad or keyboard, just the click works. The trackpad doesn't work beyond that - no movement. No response from keyboard. Not sure where to go with this. Everything is measuring fine that I can think to check.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Keyboard/Trackpad
threads.message: Have you tried a known good trackpad flex and trackpad?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Keyboard/Trackpad
threads.message:
TP/KB not working on OSX and boot menu too?
If yes, try known good TP board/flex.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Keyboard/Trackpad
threads.message: Yes, definitely tried known-good trackpad, cable and keyboard. I have a bunch of these boards around so I double-checked with a good board and all of the test parts are confirmed good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Keyboard/Trackpad
threads.message:
"TP/KB not working on OSX and boot menu too?"
???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Keyboard/Trackpad
threads.message: Yes, it does the same thing in the boot menu. Just has the trackpad click. No Force Touch click. No movement. No keyboard.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Keyboard/Trackpad
threads.message:
First, check basic voltages for J4802.
Next, post <CHIP>U4910</CHIP> voltages; both cases, boot menu and OSX logged in.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Keyboard/Trackpad
threads.message: Thanks, that helped get me there. It's a strange one. <SIGNAL>3V3_S3</SIGNAL> was unstable at around .5V for a few seconds at startup and then would come up to 3.3V. That was keeping the trackpad from getting power initially which seemed to keep it off after that. I switched out <CHIP>U8010</CHIP> and <SIGNAL>3V3_S3</SIGNAL> comes up to 3.3V immediately now. All is good. Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Keyboard/Trackpad
